Mount Holly N. J.
August 25th 1870
Dear General,
Yours without any date is at hand and right glad I was to get it. I expect those Indians have worried you nearly to death this summer, but if you get them to bring in the captives and stolen stock it will be a big triumph. 

    I have been running around considerably since I last wrote you, to Long Branch, Saratoga and Boston; and between the Homeopathic medicine, sea  bathing and Saratoga water, am much improved in health. I have not had a chill for three weeks and feel in hopes I have broke them for good. While at Saratoga I met Gen'l. Hazen, He told me thought he would go to Europe.

to witness the war.   He left that evening for Long Branch, saw the President, got permission and has already sailed.  I guess the Indian Superintendency business played out and he had to make some other move or join his regiment.

    I have today mailed to the Post Adjutant at Fort Sill, a subpoena to appear at Van Buren Nov. 14th and an application for permission to delay joining my station until my services have been dispensed with.  If granted, this will give me the month of October and save my travelling over the road from Sill to Smith three times.  I will be much obliged if you will put an endorsement on it that will make it go through.  I might send my own certificate as to my health, but I don't want to do so if I can avoid it and as I have not been treated by an army surgeon I

could send no other.

    Our mutual friends in this part of the country are all well and desire to be remembered.
    Mrs. Campion wanted to know if we raised chickens at Ft. Sill, and told me to tell you when she comes to take tea with you to please have chickens.
    I received a letter from Lt. Taylor at Washington yesterday.  He sent me a copy of Capt. Cox's sentence.  He is cashiered and his sentence is awful, and I understand Graham's is worse.  I suppose you will have received them before this.  Kind regards to Mrs. Grierson.  Let me hear from you again before I leave these parts.  Going from Albany to Boston the other day I met Mrs. Nordstrom enroute to Maine only eight days out from Fort Arbuckle.
              Very Truly yours,
                 S. L. Woodward

[along left side of page]
I received a letter from John yesterday.   They were all well I want [underline] to try and stop with him a few days as I return.

on the other hand, the forbearance you have been compelled to exercise, has not been without profit to the government.    The end has been attained and an expensive war avoided.  It will require time and patience to settle those fellows, besides much policy, but it seems to me that we are every day getting them more in our power, and while the best civilizers, good food and comfortable clothing and plenty of them are furnished by the government, one half the battle is won.    I think if two or three of the Kiowa chiefs were killed off it would have a good effect.

I shall furnish a certificate
of health to cover my time,
but I dont want to do
this if I can help it.
If a copy of the order intended
for me should come to Ft Sill,
please have it sent to me 
at Paducah. I shall 
leave here for Paducah
Oct 10th, and shall remain
there until about Nov
1st when I shall leave

November 14th.
I am stopping here with
Mr + Mrs Campion, who

Kind regards to Mrs.
Grierson. Write me
again and direct to Paducah.

S L Woodward

Fort Smith Ark
Nov. 24, 1870
Dear General,

                       Yours directed to me at this point is at hand.  The Court has got through with me, but three of the five men Lt. Harmon turned over to me are witnesses in the murder case from Camp Supply, and I think it best to remain until the case is disposed of and bring them all with me.  I shall, consequently not get away until sometime next week.  Today is "Thanksgiving" and of course nothing doing in the court.  I have orders enough here for apples, potatoes and oil enough to load three wagons.  I will bring your oil any how, but cant promise about anything else.  I hear Robinson is coming down and look for him, thinking he may have another wagon.
   Dr. Brown left here on Monday morning the 20th.  Had I have known of the

train from "Sill" being at "Gibson", it would have been as well to have sent five or six wagons down here instead of four as came for the Doctor, and then I might have brought everything out, which is needed.

   I am now in excellent health if it only lasts - was awful sick for about ten days while at Paducah.
   Please say to Lt. Keyes, his trunk was sent out by McKibben on a train which left here Nov. 7th.  I suppose it has reached him ere this.
   The Ambulance and wagon team turned over by Harmon are in pretty poor condition, but I am trying to get them in shape while I delay here.
           Kind regards to all
                                                 Truly yours
                                                         L. Woodward

Fort Sill I. T.
August 30. 1871
Dear General,
Yours of the 14th, just before you left Otter Creek came duly to hand, which was the last we heard from you, until yesterday "Kicking Bird" came in and brought yours of the 19th letters for Mr. Latum and for several of the ladies.  Mr. Latum issued him rations and he went away much pleased.  Lone Wolf was also in, but I did not see him.                   We are getting along very nicely here.  The stone work of the laundress' quarters &c is all done, the drain is dug and ready for the masons, the cellar & foundation walls of Q. M. Store house done and the cellar of the Commissary ware house dug and masons just commencing work on it. Digging this was a hard jog, the ground being so hard.
I am as busy as a sailor all the time and have been particularly so

since Major Gibson Inspector General arrived.  He was here about a week and left day before yesterday.  He made a pretty thorough inspection of the post and troops, went through all unserviceable property &c.  He was not as particular as Davis, but tolerably thorough.
The Brown, Spencer, Nordstrom Clique had their axes to grin and buzzed him considerably, the whole of them on the quarter question and each one on his own particular troubles.  I opened out on him on the quarter question as I knew these other parties were doing it, and he requested me to give him a written statement, which I did in which I represented your position as well as I knew how.  I have a copy to show you when you return.  I prepared for him a large amount of information concerning the post and troops, such as Inspectors require in making up their reports.
Spencer interviewed him about

his transfer business and I furnished him copies of all endorsements in the case, particularly the ones concerning his frosted feet in 1863 [4 words underline] whereby he is unfit for cavalry, but wants to go into infantry.  Rockwell on some of them represented the McKibben interest, relative to the latter's application for quarters "according to rank" and I furnished him with copies of all the correspondence in that case.  I don't think any of the points they made will reflect credit on them.
Major Gibson is a very nice gentleman.  He said he was sorry you were not here, and that Gen'l. Pope supposed you would be back by the time he arrived. I think he was generally well pleased with the post &c.  He spoke very highly of our Signal Corps and said Gen'l. Davis told him he would find our Headquarter books & papers all right.   
Hazen has gone on leave which is the reason he came.
Major Schofield is running things all

right and we are getting along well.  I like him very much.
The Commissary & Q. M. stores are arriving fast, but the hard bread is not here yet.
Your family are all well, but the baby who is a little delicate.

                   Regards to all
                            Truly yours
                              S. L. W.

Fort Sill I.T.
May 15. 1872
Dear General.
I have not heard from you yet except through Mrs. Grierson. She told me what you said about moving Regimental Headquarters to Gibson. If you find it necessary to stay there permanently of course it would be best. I don't care about being the Adjutant of the regiment any great length of time for any of the other Field Officers. I don't believe, however, we shall ever find as desirable a cavaly post for our regiment as this is at present, and therefore unless the work you have to do down there is going to be permanent, I don't believe it best to drop this post or to give an officer of another regiment a chance to come in here and command a part of yours if it can be helped. 
You know best what you have to

do at Gibson and if you are going to stay there, I don't want to stay here. 
The new warehouse will have the roof on and floor in by Saturday or Monday night and I shall then put the new store in there as they arrive. They are coming in now very fast. I have received invoices of everything shipped and my estimates have been filled complete.
The McKibbin, Walsh, Pratt clique are as usual hostile and treacherous. I suggest to you it would be a good idea to burst it up. I think the Major might be made useful, if he is of any use anywhere, at the end of the track or some such place, and Walsh has only about 15 men in his company, I think it would be a good plan to send he and his officers with the few men they have to Senita Junction or some such place, where they would have a chance to recruit. They leave no opportunity unturned to say something which sounds detrimental to you and everybody about you. McKibbin keeps himself as usual as full as the

rum he can get will make him. If he should, by any accident, fall in command here, he would doubtless displace me as a.c.s. &c by Pratt and I am satisfied that Pratt is trying to create dissatisfaction among those who are willing to listen to him, which that end in view. You have lots of friends here and they are the most useful officers on the post, and the actions of these other parties cannot help leaking out occasionally, so that I can see which way the cat jumps, though they are very smooth in my presence. I think Pratt, from his actions, thinks he will pull through all right with the Court and if he does, is fool enough to think he has gained a victory, after all his trouble, and I think it would be a good idea to put? him where he would have something else to do besides criticise his com'd'g, officer's actions, and where he would be harmless as any note. He is a sneak of the first water. I write at length on this subject because I think now is the time, while you

are changing companies to smash the clique. Your barrel of coal oil arrived a few days ago and is, I believe all right. I had it put in the cellar for Mrs. Grierson this morning.
All are well here. Conpete got back all right on the 3.d Had a very pleasant trip, saw millions of buffalo and chased a few Indians one day, who looked like a war party. I hope to hear from you by the next mail. We only gt two mails per week now.
Very truly yours
S.L.W.
With regard to the rumor of Mackenzie coming here, it was based on some report from Dept H.qrs. that important changes would be made soon. I think it looks more as if he would be ordered to the Rio Grande. One company of his regiment has been sent there and they have mounted a co. of the 10th., infantry, showing the need of cavalry. I enclose some newspaper slips which show that things are mixed down there.
S.L.W.

Fort Sill I. T.  Sept. 3d 1874
Dear General,

                         Your two last letters of August 10th and 21st are at hand.      The cause of our folks not hearing from me, was because one or two mail bags were sent from here to Caddo and returned here without being opened and my letters were delayed.  I always write home once a week or oftener.  Through the newspapers you have doubtless, by this time, heard of our little row at the Wichita Agency.  Gen'l. Davidson heard that a band of Noconis under Big Red Food who belong here and should have come in here before Aug. 3d & enrolled themselves, had slipped into the Wichita Agency and squatted alongside of the Peneteghkas.  He determined to go and arrest them and bring them here. We started at 10 o'clock

at night with 4 cos. of the reg't. (C, H, E, &L) and reached the Agency at 12 the next day.  The Peneteghkas were camped just to the left of the Crossing of the Washita on the north side and these Noconis next to them.  We crossed the river & formed line and sent for Big Red Food & the other headmen of that band.  Red Food was right there and another fellow called Black Duck, which were all the men there who owned to being Noconis.  Their camp, however, consisted of about sixty lodges.  Gen'l. Davidson told Red Food that he had not come in to be enrolled at the proper time, that he was known to have been on the war path and that he must surrender his arms and go with him band back to Ft. Sill.  He agreed to do it, after earnest persuasion from Tosawa & Esetoyet, and I was sent with Morrison's Company dismounted, into the camp to receive the arms.  When I got there, they surrendered

three old pistols and an old carbine, when a question arose about bows & arrows.  I sent back to Gen'l. D. to know if he wanted these given up, & also about packing the camp, as he had said before, he intended to stand back with the outfit that night.  He sent word back to me to take up Bows & Knives and that the camp must be ready to move in two hours.  Red Food then said he would not give up his Bows & arrows or Knives and that he would not go to Fort Sill.  He wanted to parley and make some other arrangement with me.  I told him I could make no arrangement and that he must go back and see the Comd'g. officer again.  In the meantime 50 or 100 Indians of all tribes gathered around on their horses and the thing looked squally.  I succeeded in getting him part way back

when suddenly with a yell, he jumped his horse through the guard, who all fired on him, and ran like lightning.  The men think they wounded him but dont know.  We mounted the command and started into the Noconi camps when a party of Kiowas fired upon our rear from the Indian Commissary Building.  (You will remember it as Shirley's store when we were there in 1871 or 72.)  We dismounted and Little's company charged the building and drove them out.  We had some more scattered skirmishing during the day and again the next morning, but with no serious results.  We had three [strike] four men wounded and about six horses.  Horace Jones' horse Dan, was wounded and died that night.  My horse was also slightly wounded in the neck.  We got the friendly Indians who belong there, back again into their agency & leaving 4 companies there, returned to this post, after an absence of a week

2

    The weather was fearfully hot especially on the days of the fight and we all came near being overcome with the heat.  One man died from the heat, on the return trip.    Col. Baird Inspector Gen'l. from Chicago arrived here two days ago, and this morning reviewed and inspected us mounted.  Night before last Gen'l. Augur with his son Jake and Capt Comly (Ordnance Dept.) arrived from Griffin, under escort of two companies 9th Cav'y.  I believe he intends to stay here until we start in the field, which will not now, I think, be before the 15 or 18th.
  The programme is this, and I accidentally saw a copy of Mackenzie's letter of instructions the contents of which are probably not known to anybody else here.  He left Griffin some days ago with 8 cos. cavalry & 5 of Infantry for his

old supply camp on the Double Mtn Fork of the Brazos.  He expects to get away from there about the 15 or 18th of this Month.  He skirts up along the edge of the Stoked Plains to about the head of the Red river, thence down it or the north or Salt Fork and so on to Fort Sill.  A Column of six cos. of Cavalry & two of Infantry under Lt. Col. Buell 11th Inf. has already left Griffin and I understand since our row at the Wichita Agency, is coming here.  It was intended to act between here and Mackenzie's Column and is under Mackenzie's order's. We leave here about the 15th with 7 cos. cavalry & 3 of Infantry, march to the Wichita Agency, thence up the Washita and perhaps across to the head of North Fork Red river as circumstances dictate.  Mackenzie's orders are, to come in to Fort Sill, and upon his arrival here assume entire

control of Indian Affairs until he hears from Department H. Qrs.  This I know as I say it in a rough draft of his instructions.  I don't think Davidson knows this, but it virtually gives Mackenzie the control of the entire Campaign so far as this Department is concerned.

   I wish you were here right now, I think the 10th Cavalry would stand a better chance to get credit for what it does; besides I don't consider Mackenzie a very safe man to conduct a large campaign or to control indian affairs.  He knows nothing of the routine of indian business on this reservation or at this post.
   I forget to tell you, We have a small portion of the Kiowas here under Kicking Bird and his brother Son of the Sun, the balance are out & fought us at the Agency.  Kicking Bird tried to control the tribe for peace but could not do it.  then we have the

most of the Yamparicas here; one band under Esenanica, came in since the enrolling, met us at Cache creek as we returned from the Wichita Agency and surrendered their arms.  The surrender did not amount to much, only seven old pistols & two old muzzle loading rifles having been given up.  But still it is an entering wedge.

   Since the last turn of events, our supply camp on Otter Creek is broken up and everything is brought in.
   Big Red Food is the Indian whom you will remember had a row with a soldier at the sutler store and struck him with his Tomahawk, and whom I arrested by your order.
   We burned up his camp about sixty lodges & all their traps, but preserved the feneteghka ? intact.             During the fight, the Kiowas murdered six citizens whom they found out in the vicinity of the Agency.  Among these was Osborne a white man & son in law of Black Beaver.

It was issue day when we reached the Agency and the Caddo's, Wichitas & the whole outfit were in there.  Just before the firing occurred, I knew from appearances there was going to be a row and I told Tosawa, & Wanloope of the Caddos, to get their people away from there.  If they had not have do so, there would undoubtedly have been some of these friendly bands killed by our fire.  As it was, the Kiowas fired on the Caddos and burned some of their houses.

    Schofield is expected back here every day, and in case he arrives before we leave, is to have command of the Cavalry on the expedition; for you must know Davidson has organized his command, (7 cos. cav. & 3 of Inf.) into a brigade.  Smither is his A.A.A.G., so announced in an order which is already printed, but not yet issued.  I go now, ad Adjt.

of the Cavalry, but I don't know who will be my regimental commander, either Schofield or Carlton.  Imagine to yourself a Cavalry command under either, accomplishing anything.  Davidson intended in the first place to go along in a sensible way, with a very small staff and no fuss or feathers; but he saw Miles' order, organizing his command, in the papers, in which an A. A. G.   A. D. C., Chief of Artillery &c &c, were announced and he determined not to be outdone in that respect.

                            Sept. 4th.

This morning's mail brought the news of the new recruiting detail and several of us are hoping you will come out here in time to take the controlling hand in this fall's campaign.  Col. Wood 11th Infantry is ordered here temporarily to command while Davidson is out.  He don't bring his family.

I will close this and write you more hereafter, in case there is anything important.
      Kind regards to Mrs. Grierson and the family.
                             Truly Yours
                                  S. L. Woodward

OFFICE OF
J. S. EVANS & CO.
MILITARY AND INDIAN TRADERS,
Fort Sill, Indian Territory, Sept. 9, 1874
Dear General

                          We start in the morning, 6 cos. cavalry, 3 of infantry, 45 wagons and 40 Indian scouts.  We go to Fort Cobb, thence up the Washita and thence as circumstances dictate, perhaps to Sweet Water & McClellan Creek.

Pratt is buzzing for the recruiting detail, has even had the brass to interview me about it, but I think like you, he has no claims for it or on you for anything.  Kelly is crazy for it, Beck I believe, also wants it, though he has said nothing to me about it.  I have heard no one else express a wish.

Pratt has lately had the worst reprimand from Dept. Hd. Qrs. I ever saw, in the shape of an endorsement on some papers.  He said that his name had never appeared at Dept. Hd. Qrs. except in connection with charges and complaints and it was hoped that this Officer would find some other way of bring his name before the Dept. Commander.

   He is in charge of the Indian Scouts on this trip.  Augur goes up to the Wichita Agency tomorrow, thence back here and back home.  He talks of coming again in October.
   I have not time to write more, Nolan with his company is here under Buell and with 5 cos. 9th Cavalry.  His company is in splendid trim, but he don't want to serve under Davidson.  In fact he hates him the worst kind

D. had his company sent away from here when he came here and assumed Command.  Now he wants to get it back.  Applied for it today, but Augur refused the request.

    Kind regards to all.  I will scratch you while on the march if I have a change to send it in.
    If you should come here before we return. Go into my house (Schofield's old house) Louey & his wife are there keeping it and running my mess.  You will find mess and everything there, and hang up until you get straightened out, I, today, received surgeons certificate from Schofield.
                              Truly Yours
                                    S. L. W.

Camp on North Fork of Red River 
                                                                                         about 15 miles below the mouth of McClellan Cr.
                                                                                          Sept. 23. 1874

Dear General,

                        We have been camp here in the bottom for two days.  This is our 14th day out from Sill.  We went up to the Washita opposite Old Fort Cobb, thence up the south side to Rainy Mountain Creek thence up the divide, crossing to the North Fork side of it.  We have marched from 1 1/2 to 21 miles per day, one day only, making 21 miles.  Col. Miles with 8 Cos. Cavalry, & 5 of Infantry came down from Camp Supply in August, struck Indian trails on Sweet Water about 10 miles north of here, followed them to the Main Red river, had a fight with them, and drove them on to the Stalked Plains.  The Indians wee evidently fighting to save a camp which they had on Red River.  Miles pressed them slowly back and found that they had gotten everything out of the camp they could and burned the rest

They say they think they killed 17 Indians but don't know of more than two or three.  Miles only had 15 days rations with him and had to go back.  He left 2 Cos 5 Inf. on the Sweet Water about ten miles north of here and we found them there two days ago, on very short rations of had bread & coffee, not having had beef [strike] meat for 5 days.  Buffalo are very scarce, hardly any to be found.  We gave them a beef out of our herd and our Indian scouts killed them a buffalo.  Miles with 5 more companies is on the Washita about 20 miles north of them & he has some more of his troops up on the Canadian & guarding his trains from Camp Supply.  When he made his dash in August the weather was very hot and water very bad & scarce, and his horses are badly used up.  Gen'l. Davidson went over to the Camp in Sweet Water yesterday to meet Miles & just returned this morning.

  Maj. Price 8 Cav. came over from New Mexico with 4 Cos. to join Miles.  After joining, he went out to look for a train which was following him from New Mexico, and has not yet returned, although his train has got into Miles Camp on the Canadian.

Our rations are out on the 5th of October and it will take us about all we can do to get back to Sill by the time they are gone.  I cannot write more as the scout who takes this over to Miles Camp is about to start.  Gen'l. G. I think now intends to go up McClellan Creek a short distance, thence around by your old route of /71 back to Sill.
He wanted to send to "Supply" after rations, instead of Sill, but I think Miles has told him he can't get them there.

            Write me at Sill and let me know when to expect you out
                                                     Truly yours
                                                             S. L. W.

Fort Sill, I. T.
                                                          Oct. 12, 1874

Dear General

                           I returned to this Post yesterday.  Yours of the 6th reached me today.  I am sorry to hear of Edie's illness, but it is fortunate if she gets over it now instead of having it when she is older.  I have seen much of the Scarlet Fever and know its malignant nature.
                           Well General, I can't say much except what would appear to you as a growl, for nothing satisfactory has happened on our late trip and very unsatisfactory things are transpiring now.

We neither saw nor fought but two Indians, one known Mexican & one Cheyenne, both of whom rode into our Indian scouts and were captured.
We went up the Washita, thence over to Sweet Water, thence to McClellan Creek, thence across White Fish Creek & down it to the Head Waters of What you called Buck Creek thence down it on your trail of 1871 for a couple of days, thence to its mouth

thence down Red river to a point near the mouth of Salt Fork, thence home.  We travelled a good part of the time virtually on your 71 trail, after finding and crossing it.  If you remember right, you travelled on that trip 420 miles & were gone 18 days, & lost one horse.  We travelled 450 miles and were out 30 days, & lost 36 horses & 22 mules.  We started with 10 days forage & 25 days rations.  We had to piece out the rations & the forage was all gone long before our return.  We fooled & frithered our time away and accomplished nothing.  The balance of the command is fearfully used up, horses dead poor equipments played out and the train so badly used up that it will be sheer folly to attempt to haul anything with it this winter, and besides, there is not half large enough train to haul the necessary supplies for a campaign which must go to the brakes of Red River, where the actually hostile Indians are.     To cap the Climax, Davidson (by Gen'l. Augur's orders he says) has encamped the command about six miles from the post, where all the forage, rations &c has to be hauled to it by this very played out train, and where they get no nay, and you know the grass is not superb this time

Sheridan is looked for here daily, but I don't think anybody knows positively whether he is coming or not.

           Excuse the pencil.  I was ranked out of my quarters while I was gone and have not got unpacked & straightened out since my return.
           Kind regards to Mrs. Grierson.  I hope the other children will escape the Scarlet Fever.                    Write me and let me know about when you will return, also what you want done if anything here, in the way of transportation to meet you, and whether Mrs Grierson & the family will come out with you.
           I am glad to hear Charley has got such a good start.  I never feared but what he would go in high and have no trouble in getting along.
           I will close as the mail goes out this morning.
                                                                               Truly Yours
                                                                                S. L. W.

If a cold wet month comes, such as we are liable to have this time of year, we will lost at least an average of ten horses to the company, and any quantity of mules.                  Satanta, Big Tree, Woman's Heart and about 40 more Kiowa & Cheyenne Bucks with a lot of squaws & children came in the Cheyenne Agency & surrendered, and today Satanta, Big Tree, Woman's Heart & another, arrived here under guard and a company of the 6th

Oct 13th I have thought well over your offer to move to wire? me the Recruiting detail, and I feel that I would like very much to go and that it will be only justice to my family to avail myself of the opportunity. unclear the next detail is made,

Fort Sill I. T.
Oct. 15, 1874
Dear General,

                      I have a few moments leisure and thought I would write you, so as to keep up the chain of events which are transpiring here, and which will interest you more from the fact that you expect so soon to come back.  I believe I told you in my last, Satanta, Big Tree, Woman's Heart and another chief are here in irons.
  Today about 33 more bucks and perhaps 90 or 100 women & children with their ponies, lodges & poles and everything they have came in  The bucks were immediately put in the new ice house (which is a new store building, but without roof except sheeting) under guard, the ponies taken away from them and the women & children sent down to the Agency.  We have now about 37 bucks under guard and about 400 ponies, mules & colts; then there are about 1000 more indians about the post, the male proportion of

which are supposed to be disarmed.  I received the arms of two bands myself.  Altogether there have been perhaps 125, rifles, pistols & bows given up.  Most of these have manufactured new bows since. A dispatch arrived here yesterday from MacKenzie to Augur, stating that the Indians attacked him on the night of the 26th Sept. and again on the night of the 27th, and that on the 28th he struck them in a long Canon at the head of the Red river, where they could see him a long way off.  He claims to have killed 3 Indians whose bodies he got and captured 1400 ponies, mules & colts, about 1000 of which he had shot & kept the balance.

    Sheridan is between here and Caddo and expected in tomorrow.
    Davidson has made a strong recommendation to Augur for the establishment of a catonment on McClellan Creek, to consist of about 12 companies, Cavalry & infantry.  He made this recommendation in a letter to Augur while we were out, and which has not yet reached him as he left here before it arrived.

He undoubtedly intends to make the same recommendation to Sheridan and urge it in such a way that he Davidson will perhaps be ordered to establish it, as he has nine companies now here available, though badly broken down. Dear General,

Pepoon committed suicide day before yesterday in camp near this place, by shooting himself through the head.  It was a cool deliberate act.  He quietly went into his tent, laid down on his cot, held the pistol to his head with one hand and pulled the trigger with the other.  The report was deadened so that he [strike] it was not discovered for more than an hour afterwards, when he was sent for to come to dinner; although at the time it occurred perhaps a dozen officers were in and around their tents on the same line with his. This last I tell, not from a desire to circulate it, but because I want [strike] think you ought to know it.

He took an hour in the evening

between 10 + 11 O’clock when hardly anyone was stirring about and I happened to be out, to set fire to my tent.  A soldier happened to discover it and put it out before any damage had been done. At any rate, it is a bore scrotch? that I was not burned out bag and baggage - all my personal property and records and my troop records. take place this spring and that it was indicated that Eggleston was to have charge of them.  I hope you will stop this.  He is not fit to go into the field in charge of men.  As soon as he is out from control or where he has no one to watch home he will get whiskey and do the most outrageous things.  He is lost to all sense of honor and it is not fair to soldiers to send them out under such a man.  He neglects them and becomes thoroughly oblivious of his duties and responsibilities. Eggleston with doing it.  Col. J. Wants to relieve him as signal

whom he can induce to loan to him.  I think I have said enough to indicate that in my opinion he ought not be trusted, and moreover he will probably be in very serious trouble before long. and I hope will catch them.  But you will get all of the news of this by telegraph before this reaches you.  With best regards I am very truly yours S. L. Woodward

There was such a quantity of everything left that Major Kimball sent for the married men to come back in the evening and bring their wives, which they did - and the coming i and going out lasted until eleven o'clock - some of Henry's men gave a concert that night in town - They had give Major Kimball a complimentary ticket -he sent to the hall for them - had them brought to his house - and treated them to the best he had- so no one seemed to be forgotten.  The next day Mrs. Kimball sent the remains of the feast to the poor of the town and neighborhood. Major Kimball is a good man.  I do not suppose a more strictly honest man exists.  His character is in such striking contrast to that of the other quartermasters big and little that I have fallen in with in my short army experience that I cannot avoid remarking upon it - How much good it would do some who are puffed up with authority to take lessons from him.  This much for New Years - Henry and Lieutenant Harmon have only the most pleasant intercourse with the officers here all of whom are gentlemanly - Col. Floyd Jones the commander is a gentleman indeed and we are very sorry to lose him.  He had

obtained a twenty day leave and starts tomorrow for Leavenworth where he will endeavor to obtain permission to apply at the War Dept for an eight months extension to his present leave when he proposes to go to  his home in New York City and then to Europe.  Col Floyd Jones is a cultivated gentleman but as simple in manner as a child.  No more observant person or one better calculated to appreciate them could desire to see the Old world works of art - I like such Americans to go abroad to show people across the water what sort of men we can make - the Adjutant also is a gentleman and so far as we can see no difference is made between officers of white and colored regiments at this Fort. The officers of company "M" certainly have not the slightest pretext for complaint.  It pleases me to be able to say this - because we had heard such blood and thunder stories at Head quarters.  Col Floyd Jones spent this evening with us - He says Major Bryant will take command in his absence has good soldierly qualities and will make a pleasant commander of the District.  All Henry asks is to have a soldier over him - he does not expect to have any trouble - tho Major Bryant is given to strong drink when he can get it, which is a pity --------- he too is unmarried.

Our kitchen is not yet done - the delay was caused by a continuance of snowy cold weather, but when we heard that Col Floyd Jones was going to leave Gibson so soon Henry determined not to wait any longer but to have a supper for the officer before the Col went away - We finished the kitchen chimney with a barrel - fastened tents around the sides of the kitchen and moved the stove in and I commenced making active preparations - this was Wednesday - by Friday everything was ready and Henry gave his invitations.  Mine were ten gentlemen at table and our bill was as follows - Roast Turkey with gravy and preserved cherries - Green ham stuffed and baked with applesauce - Roast Possum with onion(a popular dish).  Prairie chickens baked with sage stuffing and gravy.  Wild duck, roasted. Quail, larded. Meadow larks -larded - stewed rabbit with cream gravy - all hot. Then Old ham spiced and baked - and Chicken salad.  Baked tomatoes -  hot - Hot mince pie and jelly pudding cold.  Charlotte Russe and wine jelly and apple Float followed - Then coffee -  hot and strong - From the first apple toddy our only strong drink was given to each guest - and then kept supplied with it all the time - it was first rate - too and much praised.

as was every thing else on the table - You will wonder where we got enough china, glass and cutlery for a supper.  Our table was ten feet long  and four feet wide and was as full as it could well be.  I bought a very handsome linen damask table cloth and we had on hand- bought more than half the things I though we should need them some time or other - and we have now enough for a moderate family.  The extra things we got from the ((Sutler?)) and Mrs. Kimball - I missed you I can tell you - We had the bed moved into the kitchen.  Henry decorated our room beautifully with cedar - he broke off single branches and stuck them along the rafters - not thick enough to hide the clapboard roof however - which showed its gray and brown wood colors beautifully through the bright green.  The vases had grasses  - green and cedar and red berries in them - your pretty vase was on the mantle - Miseltoe with its white berries hung over the glass - and there were pretty things over the pictures - There was a glass lantern hung up in the green at one end of the roof - our larger bronze lamp on the table with a sperm candle at each end - a glass lamp in the corner on my work table - and ten sperm candles on the mantle shelf - These with a bright wood fire made the room quite brilliant and the officers came at eight and left a little before twelve o'clock - They enjoyed everything and Henry's supper was pronounced the handsomest thing of the kind they had ever seen west of the Mississippi River.  Everything was done first 
right - nothing cooked too much or too little.  I had no cake ex cept what was

4
in the Charlotte Russe, because I had seen so much cake everywhere - and knew they must ll be tired of it - at any rate it would be no rarity - For bread I had cream biscuit - The whole supper was cooked on and in our little stove - and I did the most of it myself - I did not come into the room until the gentlemen left the table. 
The day before was pay day and all the officers and men were in fine spirits.  I had a red and white worsted ((soutay?))from the 1st Sergeant - a pair of buckskin riding gloves from one of the men - and a russian bath towel from another for a pay day present - Others wanted to make me a present but I told them they had better save their money.
Henry wished very much to have a game supper before he left Riley - but the General was away and after he came back tho we tried hard we could not get the game.  then Major Davis came and I got sick - so that it seemed impossible to do it - and besides you know how busy Henry was all the time.  All yesterday I was bush clearing away the debris of the supper.  I gave something to each of the non-commissioned Officers - a taste of all that was left - and s far as I could to the privates.  The all seem so willing

at all times to help me do anything I ask them that I cannot help feeling grateful.  Not once on the march nor since we have been in camp have I seen anything that could offend the most fastidious female, and although our house is just at the head of the company ((shed?)) days pass without my hearing an oath, and no worse punishment than carrying a log - or standing at Parade Rest has ever been awarded any of the men - and Henry is complimented continually upon the good discipline of his company - He has no better men than the three companies are composed of - but he makes "moral suasion" and a good example go as far as it will and consequently does not have to resort to brute force very often.
Col. Floyd Jones will get to Leavenworth about the time this letter reaches you.  I wish the General would go down to Leavenworth to see him - he would like him I know and would hear a disinterested account of the Officers and companies of his regiment in this Territory - and at the same time obtain an intelligent account of this country.  Suppose you suggest this to him - the idea has just occurred to me - and Henry thought it would be well to mention it.
The Pay Master went to Arbuckle - and a Sergeant

and ten men of Henry's company acted as escort as far as the Seminole Agency - where Co "E." is - I wrote to Mrs. Morrison (I had heard that Capt and Mrs. Robinson were at Arbuckle) and thinking she would be glad to get some gossip from Head Quarters I took the liberty of sending her your last letter to me - to read - first carefully erasing the only sentence in it which you could object to any one seeing.
Doctor Dodson tried to prejudice persons here against Henry - but as he did not create a favorable opinion of his own perfections his talk did not have much effect.  the Post surgeon here told us about it - What a puppy (I beg pardon of all young dogs) that Dodson is!  I am glad I did not go to see his wife tho I thought I ought to when you wanted me to go.
We hear favorable accounts of Company "E."  Very little is said of "D" and very bad things of "L".
The winter has been an unusually cold stormy one - so I cannot give an opinion of the climate.  Some days are charming and altho we live in a log  house and can see stars and sunshine through the roof - we have a good time and enjoy life wonderfully well - sometimes Henry has a bad headache.  Tuesday he was so sick with one that I sent for Dr. Hubbard

I was afraid he would go into spasms.  After three hours of intense suffering he became exhausted and went to sleep - a long nap partially relieved him, so you see we have our trials too.  Bless the children!  I wish I could see them.  What a bouncer the young general must be - I wonder when we shall all be together again.  Perhaps next summer if no new Post is built in this territory.  We speculate a good deal upon what will become of us - Lt. Harmon wants his wife with him but she will not leave her children and he does not like to expose them to the climate of Gibson.  We  hope Lt. Lee will prove agreeable and a good Officer - There is a good Officer's mess at the ((unclear)) but it is so far off that Lt. Harmon boards with us - tomorrow we expect a woman - colored of course - whose looks I like - tho none of them know much down here - not enough to be very fine ladies - and above work.  I am happy to say one of the Sergeants (Jefferson)is about to be married.  Tell Parker that his brother is well.  Louis has been sick with pain in his back for several days  - he comes every morning for ginger or something to warm him up - he is the greatest curiosity I ever saw - and very faithful.  Henry has had no trouble at all with him.  Capt Robinson has been ordered to this Post to finish up the work of his survey of the reservation  he was called away suddenly by the illness of his wife.

Dear Genl. 
I have just returned from a trip to ((Kearns Canon?)) and the Mogrie Villages and across the Navajo Country and around the Agency.  I met Lt. Stosenberg 6th Cavalry at Fort Difranco, he had just come in from an extended examination of the water reserves of the Navajo Reservation and has forwarded to Gen Grierson a report of his observations.  Something should be done to improve the water facilities both for tock and irrigation.  there is an abundance of water for both if properly developed and controlled - Ex Agt Patterson squandered or made way with more than double the amount of money needed to have put it in excellent shape - the present Agt Vandever is a good Mr. Patterson' administration was a great

draw back and injury to the Navajos.  I have recommended to the Secy Intr, that the work be done under the supervision of an army officer or officers tho selected by you - and cited the work done of Jan Carlos at almost no expense - certainly none to the Intr Dept.  I think the best plan would be to send two officers - with two or three men, to select two places or three and systematically do the work - The agent should be furnished the necessary funds to pay for labor, as the Indians draw no rations - but are willing to do their part without pay in their own locality.  You can select some active young officer who would be glad to take the job.  There are a certain class of young Bucks among the Navajos who don't realize the power of the Govt and some day trouble may occur - up about Tuba City and Chi-a-lee Valley they are a tough crowd - Vandever is full of nerve and good judgement - but if he should require backing

by the Military force, it should be a strong one to impress them, that the Govt can enforce law and order among them - They learned under Patterson to treat with contempt all authority - Force is all they will respect.  If an occasion should arise where troops are needed - I respectfully suggest that a strong force be shown them.  I go to Mescalero agy from here and will return in 8 days and then go to San Carlos - I think I would like to go from Ft. Apache and then to Wilcox - and if convenient get a sight at the Indians near Ft Apache - When will you be out this way?  I hope you will see proper to suggest some plan to the Secy to improve the water facilities and and matters on the Navajo Reservation - Vandever is doing very well - but if he is changed an officers should be placed there - 
Yours Truly 
Lt. C.Armstrong

Sir  I have the honor to report that during my temporary command of the Post consequent upon the Colonels absence at Fort Smith, Arkansas, it was reported to me by the Post-Commissary of Subsistence, Lieut Rees Sixth Infantry that Captain H.E. Alvord, 10th Cavalry casually at the Post, had purchased during his absence from his office and against his consent a large amount of Subsistence-Stores very much in excess of what would be required for the use of Captain Alvord and family on their contemplated trip to Camp Witchita, Medicine-Bluff, for which point Captain Alvord was en-route to join his Company.  I directed Lieut. Rees to order Capt. Alvord to return the stores purchased and gave the Lieut. verbal instructions to allow the Captain to procure supplies sufficient to subsist himself and family as far as Fort Arbuckle.

To this order Captain Alvord replied in a long communication complaining of my action and refused to return the stores.  I returned this communication with an endorsement  directing Captain Alvord to immediately comply with my order, this was handed him by the Post-Adjutant, Lieut Rees who was directed in case of Captain Alvord persisting in his refusal to obey my orders, to place him in arrest.  He again refused obedience and the Adjutant placed him in Arrest, he (Captain Alvord) remarking at the time, that he denied my right to place him in arrest.  Subsequently a written order was issued and send him placing him in arrest and assigning him his limits - the last, being the limits of the post.  Captain Alvord declining to deliver the stores or to give any information as to their where abouts I directed Lieut. Rees to search for them, having with him a guard and when found to have possession of them and return them to his store-house.  This was done and the stores found packed away in Captain Alvords chests and boxes in the basement of General Griersons Quarters.  Most of the store were recovered, some small articles could not be found, having evidently been secreted by Captain Alvord.

In order to recover the stores the boxes containing them had
to be broken upon as Captain Alvord refused lend any
assistance or give up his Keys.
I regretted to have been compelled to have resorted to force
in this matter, but I had no other course left me.
I had either submit to open defiance of my orders or 
to enforce them at all hazards
The stores were procured by Captain Alvord  on the 13th inst.?
and were recovered on the 14th

         In conclusion I have to call your attention

to the fact that Captain Alvord left this Post on the 19th
inst. without having been previously released from arrest.

                    Very respectfully
                  Your obs. Servant

Colonel:  Having heard that it is contemplated to raise corn upon the Military Reservation for the use of the Government, we have the honor to submit the following propositions in regard thereto, subject to the approval of the Post Commander or proper authority  We propose to make all necessary improvements, including buildings, fencing and the thorough cultivation of a quantity of land on this Reservation, sufficient to furnish the amount of corn required by or for the use of the Government fo the ensuing four years ending February 1st 1875, agreeing to sell and deliver

To the Assistant Quartermaster at this Post any portion or the whole amount of corn raised by us on the Reservation, at the rate of seventy-five cents (75 cts) per bushel in the ear, or the additional amount of fifteen cents (15 cts) per bushel if shelled and sacked, and at the expiration of the time mentioned will transfer to the U.S. Government all right and title to the buildings or other improvements made by us on the above mentioned land.  In the event of any failure on our part after the 1st year to raise the quantity of corn required for the use of the Government at this Post during the time named in this proposition, we will agree to buy and deliver to the A.Q.M a sufficient amount to make up any such deficiency at the exact cost of the corn delivered to the A.Q.M without any remuneration to ourselves in the premises  Should this meet a favorable

consideration we will be prepared to give any required security for the faithful and thorough performance of the work mentioned in the above proposition, and are prepared to commence operations at once if authorized to do so. In the event of a disapproval by the proper authorities, and the awarding to other parties the right to prosecute the work,  we respectfully request that such parties may be required to remunerate us for the actual cost of any improvements made in the accomplishment of the work contemplated. Lieut. J. Will Myers,
Post Adjutant
Sir,

           I have the honor to report, that on the 20th of April 1871, I received an order to witness the issue of Annuity Goods to the Kiowa, Comanche and Apache Indians, by the Agent for those Indians, Mr. Lawrie Tatum, vide S. O. No. 67 Hd. Qrs. Fort Sill I. T. April 20th 1871    The goods were issued to the head men of the tribes, at different dates from April to the Middle of June 1871, as they came in from time to time; and in Equitable proportions, according to the numbers composing each band. 
    The Apaches were issued a must greater amount, pro rata than either the Kiowa or Comanches, a larger quantity having been received for them than for either of the others.  The only dissatisfaction apparent among the Indians was caused by this unequal distribution, but as a general thing; they were pleased and satisfied.   The goods were of a superior quality, and the variety and selection excellent, and well adapted to the Indian wants.    Several bands of the

Comanche and Kiowas were not issued to, having failed to make their appearance.

                                 Very Respectfully
                                  Your obdt Servt
                                      L H Carpenter
                                      Capt. 10th Cavalry
